rest_name: Ippoh Tempura Bar by Ginza Ippoh
comment: Excellent all round experience. Excellent food, excellent pace and excellent atmosphere. Small and intimate and well worth the cost. We thoroughly enjoy it every time we go.

rest_name: Ippoh Tempura Bar by Ginza Ippoh
comment: pardon my ignorance but when i first heard of them, i thought they were a chain from ipoh!little did i know that they originated from osaka with over 100 years of history!well, welcome to sg!sg really needed a specialist like you to satiate the ever demanding palates of our foodie army and you will fill nicely, a void in the premium tempura class, currently only occupied by tenshin.hidden behind a gourmet retail space in como dempsey, the whiff of safflower fried tempura pieces will be your gps.a small outpost with a lone bar counter and an additional side table good for a small group.simple set menu offering of varying prices starting at $60++ for lunch.i was able to just walk in as a solo diner, without reservations, the two times that i have dined here.but the seats did fill up quickly with most having prior bookings.so best to call ahead to avoid disappointment.cute pottery decor have attracted many wannabe buyers.no, the staff do not know where they are from and no, they are not for sale.additionally, they are glued down to avoid accidental mishaps, so do let them rest in peace.service has been friendly and attentive enough for such a casual setup being at times overwhelmed but still always courteous.freshly prepared batter thinly coats premium produce dropped into healthy non reused oil at the ideal temperature that cooks and not burn.timely rescued by expert hands and delivered piece by piece, just in time, for your gourmet indulgence. no chance to be overly oily nor lose it's light fluffy tempura crispiness.tenshin, beware!you are not alone anymore.although pricey, ippoh is comparable to you.but what ippoh does lack are comfortable bar chairs with proper foot rest.and perhaps a more innovative dessert other than the resident, run of the mill, green tea ice cream.

rest_name: Ippoh Tempura Bar by Ginza Ippoh
comment: Been interested in trying this restaurant since it's opening about 6 months ago. This is a chain of up market tempura restaurants from Japan. 3 of which are in Japan. Outside Japan only 2 places. HKG and SIN. All ingredients are flown fresh from Japan. It is supposedly one of 2 restaurants that specialize in tempura in SIN, the other being in the Regent hotel. Service was friendly and attentive, they provided explanations of the food we ate plus the best way to eat together with which condiments. It's pretty basic and quite casual so no stress. The food was super fresh and eaten within seconds of it being cooked. Although everything was fried, the batter was light and everything was very tasty. Outstanding was the tofu with uni, the chawanmushi with foie gras was the best I have ever tasted and the rice with black truffle, which was at the end of the meal was incredible. Full as I was, I could have eaten another bowl. Was it worth the $200 per person? That really depends on each individual. My family agreed that it was.

address: 109 Mount Faber Rd Faber Peak Singapore 099203 Singapore
comment: A place w a v nice view n good food .... however there were 5-6 staff but it seems like only one is actually working ... elliot has been attending to us while the others ignored us whn we raised our hands to order/bill/questions. A particular waitress who didnt hv a name tag was extremely rude when asking for a simple request to put the cake in the refrigerator twice.

The Korean stall is located in the centre of the Comtech foodcourt on level 1 / basement / same level as the carpark. Not much of a Korean stall since it's managed by chinese-singaporean aunties. I actually rode the bus with one of them and got some insider information into this Korean Stall. It's basically that they work hard but nobody has any Korean background or knows the in and outs of Korean food. You can taste it in the food. The ingredients are okay only, not that fresh and the kim chi is just spicy. The fish is also ok only, not that fatty but tasty. I love my food being served on a sizzling plate, that's why I come back here. The bibimbap is not that great and taste plain. You have to eat it fast otherwise your rice get's cooked to the bowl.

If you fancy conveyor belt sushi with slightly better (fish) options, then Sushiro will probably be your best bet. I've dined here many times (mostly alone) for its hassle-free concept and centrally located in Tiong Bahru. Among my go-to sushi: Jack mackerel Surf clamyellowtailOtoro (fatty tuna)UniClam Miso soupLunch or dinner crowd can get very intense, so it's recommended to make a reservation before you come. There's an app for it. As for solo diner (like me), you can always walk-in and get a seat within 10-15mins. The reservation system can get really messy, especially when I've seen families with reservation tickets and still have to wait at least 30mins.  And for that, I am subtracting one star. Overall, Sushiro is not a bad place despite a rather poor reservation system. The sushis and sashimis are fresh and reasonably priced. It's like traffic jams in big cities. You can't avoid them, but you can plan your day ahead so you don't get too stressed out. Same here. All you need is a little planning - may be eat a little earlier or later before the peak hours. They're opening another outlet in Shaw House in Orchard so keep your eyes peeled!

Fish tacos ($15.80 for 2 after GST++) - 3 starsThe tortilla and toppings made the taco. The tortilla was soft and pliable while the vegetable toppings were crunchy and fresh, and that mayo! I hate mayo unless it's done like this - tangy and complements the fish. The fish itself however had a battered exterior that was greasy and thick and the meat itself though ample was tasteless. It just doesn't even come close to those fish tacos in San Diego. I'd try something else the next time.Service - 4 starsShout out to the attentive and friendly Filipina lady! Ambience - 4 starsThis is the sort of place I'd want to hang out at with friends or on a date. Spacious!

Adios Muchachos, Barrio es deliciosa!After a less than satisfactory experience at another Mexican Outlet, I can't describe how happy I was to finally try Barrio.I've seen the place for a while now, but because the wife is not the biggest fan of Mexican food, I've never really suggested it, until one fine day, when we were at vivo with my parents, we suddenly decided, what the hell, lets go for it and it changed our lives forever. The non-fan wife has now started craving Barrio's Fish Tacos! Loaded Nachos ($13.60)Off the bat, they are very generous with the ingredients. For a snack, the Nachos came loaded on a plate, topped with a generous amount of chili con carne, jalapeños, guacamole, cotija cheese and melted cheddar. The guac was very good, fresh, clean and creamy but while it was tasty, I personally felt that there needed a bit more depth to the flavour. The chili wasn't as beefy or salty, while there weren't enough jalapeños or fresh tomatoes to add that level of acidity and the cheese didn't quite give that needed punch to lift the flavours. Again, the flavours are there but sort of all blended together with none of the ingredients really shining and bursting through. Carne Asada Rice Bowl ($14.80)This was yum on many levels. The rice was well cooked and fluffy, while the black beans added a nice crunch and depth to the flavour. The beef was tender and very tasty while the sour cream and salsa picante added a nice sour / spicy kick to not only help elevate the flavours but cut the meatiness of the dish as well. Fish Taco ($13.40 for 2 / $15.90 for 3)This was truly the star of the show. The beer battered seabass was very lightly coated and fried to perfect crispness while the fish inside was soft, moist and cooked perfectly. It was wonderfully seasoned and went perfectly well with the crisp clean vegetables. Pickled red cabbage helped bring out the sweetness of the fish and made the flavours even more appetizing while the chipotle aioli helped add a level of saltiness and pungent-ness that tied and lifted the flavours to another level. Topped with a squeeze of lime and the taco came to life, bursting with flavours and having a mint salsa party in my mouth.  Mexican fries ($4.50 or upgradable in a set)Fries were a little gimmicky, essentially being just fries with some peppery powered over. The dip the fries came with however was excellent and the portion was pretty generous. Overall, dining at Barrio reminded me of why I loved Mexican food so much. It's bright, clean flavours makes for not only an appetizing experience, but one that will leave you craving for more!

Excellent service! Special mention to Ate (the Filipina Lady) for making sure everyone is well accommodated. The carne asada wrap was nice but I guess I could have ordered the loaded nachos for more intense flavour though. I'm not really a big fun of tortilla chips but this one is different. Surprisingly, it was very tasty even without the salsa. Music is cool too! Great ambience.

Decent fish tacos and chilli cheese fries. Tacos might not sound filling for some, but just two of it and the fries had me feeling quite satisfied. The service was quite slow. If you're at Vivo and looking for casual Mexican food, this is the place for you.

I used to love this place so much until they altered their menu!! However the food is still great. Portions got a little bigger which is worth the price. Their frozen margaritas are great and will definetly give you a buzz! The atmosphere at this Barrio is better than the one in orchard in my opinion. Better location better seating and the service is faster and staff is friendlier. Good place for lunch !

Returning on the Bataam Ferry, so looking for a place to eat at Harbour Front.  Mexican food sounded good, so tried Barrios.  Ordered two chicken & two pulled pork tacos.  The tacos were street style tacos, which means small tacos for eating on the go & nothing spectacular, but edible.  Not impressed as the food and drinks are over priced, but service is okay.  I have had better Mexican food in Singapore and this not it.  Thanks for trying.  Most likely not return.

It sits in a great area, Dempsey, which by default scores high on ambiance. We sat outside and enjoyed it. Regular Mexican fare, the portions were generous. The service can be much better though. While we waited for a table, we had to keep checking back with them and point them to our own. They had to be summoned for the order and it took a while to arrive as well. It's alright for a quick Mex bite in the area.

This star only represents the flavor of the food brought to my table as the temperature was quite cold. We arrived, were seated in the middle of the restaurant and ignored the entire evening. After 20 minutes, we had to pull someone aside to take our orders. There clearly wasn't a server assigned to our table as our drinks rested at the bar behind us, and we ended up choosing to grab them ourselves. The food came out cold. One member of our party didn't receive his food until the rest of us had finished. All the while servers walked about and ignored our efforts to get their attention. No consideration for experience here. Won't be coming back.

La salsa is located at 11 Dempsey road, away from bus stops and mrts'. So bring a car or include taxis on your budget. Live band performance starts at 10pm and ends at midnight. Good thing Nick has a good voice and band, what he lacks in movement and audience interaction is compensated by his effortless singing. When my friends told me we are having a mexican friday night out. What comes to mind is songs like (Besame Mucho, or fast dance song with people wearing big hats, flowy flowery dress Etc) but the band play songs of sam smith, jessie j, adam levine etc. Two thumbs for their performance. The place is not big but just right to enjoy. They have wide selection of drinks and foods. I tried mai tai and quesadilla and nachos. And wow "The best nachos ever!" Can't help but have second servings. The staff are friendly and very attentive.

Their food was delicious! Was really impressed. Only issue was how small their outdoor smoking area was, there wasn't any space left although inside was empty. But in general it was a really good experience. I was told that they have Mexican style hotdogs here by a friend, but I was slightly disappointed that they didn't. Must have been taken off the menu due to lack of popularity which seems crazy... Who wouldn't want a Mexican style hotdog!?
Drunk review! Best Mexican food in Singapore! Stop searching. Kurobuta pork burritos great. Magaritas strong. Ribeye fajitas yummy. Pollo con molle chocolatey!!

Pretty chill place.  Came in for drinks and got an order of nachos.  Margaritas were pretty good and the staff was attentive.  The nachos weren't too gringoy-. The live music is very folky/Americana, much more so than Mexican.  Lots of Eagles, Simon and funkel, etc covers.  Decent place.

Authentic Mexican food isn't doused with seasonings and certainly not taco seasoning, so I found La Salsa much like the real deal. The restaurant has a nice ambience with a friendly and efficient staff to boot.My only complaint would be that our meals came out at different times. A minute or so would be fair.  However, there was an unpleasant stretch of time between our meals being delivered to the table. Not a typical Mexican pairing and being a lover of Moscato, I had Moscato (in which I was a bit shocked to see on the menu) and the chicken chimichanga.  Both were delightful.

Real Mexican - not Tex-Mex!  Great, fresh food and really good salsa (as their name would imply).  Queso Fundido and mole are superb.  Nice facility, great live music, pleasant, attentive staff - owners are on hand most of the time - great Mexican - Gracias!

while not the best Mexican food i have had it was not bad in a pinch.  i loved the chips and salas and the queso was pretty good as well.the beef tacos were almost like the old El Paso type you make at home in the states, but the meat was a little off tasting.  it was almost like they didn't have much taco seasoning.  but still not badthe fajitas looked the part and they had all of the stuff you need to make one.  what caught me off guard was that the chicken had more of a curry flavor than a tex-mex flavor.all that being said, i will be back as part of a progressive dinner... this will be the apps part where i eat loads of chips, queso and salsa!

I really try to temper my expectations for mexican food in singapore since I have yet to meet a mexican here.  But to be honest in the past few years Ive seen a few new places open up and I cant really say that la salsa is all that great.  Its ok if you just want a burrito and a quick mexican fix but I wouldnt say its as good as some other spots here.  They do the basics but the menu really isnt all that extensive.  The ambiance is average but nothing exciting.    The staff is very friendly and attentive.  I enjoy the burrito here. The fajitas are good but way too expensive for what you get.  I know this is singapore but the lack of free chips and salsa is really annoying.  Its just not a real mexican restaurant without it.  Its a nice spot to just come grab a drink and chill in dempsey.  Its not bad its just not great.

My expectation for Mexican food in Singapore are pretty low and yet, I still want the same kind of tacos I got in America.  The beef tacos at La Salsa, while slightly closer to Taco Bell than desired, hit the spot and make me happy.  The live music and excellent margaritas pull this into a satisfying eatery for me.  I do think it is a bit over priced since my tacos didn't come with beans and rice.  The service we received was great.

I really try to temper my expectations for mexican food in singapore since I have yet to meet a mexican here.  But to be honest in the past few years Ive seen a few new places open up and I cant really say that la salsa is all that great.  Its ok if you just want a burrito and a quick mexican fix but I wouldnt say its as good as some other spots here.  They do the basics but the menu really isnt all that extensive.  The ambiance is average but nothing exciting.    The staff is very friendly and attentive.  I enjoy the burrito here. The fajitas are good but way too expensive for what you get.  I know this is singapore but the lack of free chips and salsa is really annoying.  Its just not a real mexican restaurant without it.  Its a nice spot to just come grab a drink and chill in dempsey.  Its not bad its just not great.

address: 35 Rochester Drive #02-15 Rochester Mall Singapore 138639 Singapore
comment: I was shocked to see this place almost empty on a Saturday night despite the quality of food & service. It's probably still a treasure waiting to be discovered. Rochester Mall, I suspect, is pretty much empty during weekends save for Sunday's church goers (a famous mega church, new creation is located nearby). Rochester is situated near offices and education institutes, both of which are deserted on weekends which explains the emptiness of the place despite having a renowned chef. Executive Chef Kenny Yeo has a vast experience helming renowned restaurants in Singapore and Taipei including a 3-star Michelin hotel in France. His food speaks for itself :) & because there weren't many other guests that night the chef personally attended to our table. He made it a point to explain each of the dishes as they were served and conscientiously asked for feedback on his creations. The Food 1. scallops - Love 2. lobster bisque  - Ok. I am not a fan of lobster bisque (in generally). 3. grilled squid - Ok 4. angel hair pasta - Good5. monk fish with spaghetti squash - Love!!! 6. Waygu beef (medium) - Love!!!7. foie gras - ok. Not a fan of (in generally). Abstinence allows me to sieze the moral high ground. The Desserts 8. lemon grass macaroons - Ok9. Oprah chocolate cake - Good10. green tea cheesecake - Love11. mango sobert - Ok 12. Jasmine green tea & earl grey tea with cute butter cookies shaped like stick figures hanging at the side of the cups - Love. This one was adorable! The service Excellent. Treated us like royalty.

address: 35 Rochester Drive #02-15 Rochester Mall Singapore 138639 Singapore
comment: This is a typical fro-fro restaurant in the buona vista area. The service is attentive, and the menu is typical european style. The website mentioned that it is an epicurean restaurant, so I was expecting great things. Maybe if my expectations weren't that high, it wouldn't have been so disappointing. The dishes are average or slightly above average, but there is no outstanding dishes. I had the risotto with foie gras. The foie gras was nicely cooked, but the risotto was lacking in finesse. If the prices are lower, I would go back a second time.

My Singapore distribution partner brought me here for lunch. I was quite impressed with their offering. Located in the pleasant Vivo City Mall, this shop overlooks the water with a view toward Sentosa. The facility was nicely maintained. It created a rather appealing environment for dining. Business was brisk when we went in but we were still seated right away. The service was up to Singapore standards meaning it significantly exceeded US standards. We had the duck which was very nicely prepared. We had rice, vegetables and garlic tofu as accompaniments with tea to drink as part of the lunch set. I was rather happy with the experience in general. The price was very fair at just over $30 SGD for the two of us. My colleague picked up the tab so I did not see the final tally. But it struck me as a very good deal for the quality of the fare. If you are in the area, it is worth a stop. They apparently also have a handful of other locations around Singapore as well.

What a great kopitiam!I haven't been here in the day time, but it's wonderful coming here at night for 3 reasons: De Burg, which sells what I think are the best burgers in the country; Stew Küche, a Swiss-German stall with beer and sausages; and a drinks stall that sells not just any beer, but a large variety of hard to find ciders and beers from Sweden, the UK and Germany.I like coming here for a massive burger, with a side of sausages to share with friends, and to kick back with lots of Kopparberg pear cider or Hobgoblin beer. The beers are a little cheaper than in bars: $8-10 rather than $12-15 in most bars downtown.The kopitiam setting is awesome. They even line the tables with checked tablecloth. Very strange, but it works.

Not for the fancy food but for the nostalgic feeling.. Some say that this is the oldest and first Indian restaurant in Singapore. I like the place for its somewhat quiet and away from the chaos of everyday life. The parantha is decent but what I like is the plain dosai, egg omelate and a coffee. All this with fish gravy.For times when you just want to sit back and not be stressed, this is the place.

You know your home when there comfort food in the morning a stone throw away. Friendly owner with a slate of selection of Hong Kong style noodles, with my favorite being the dumpling noodles. They were as delicious as I remembered them from a year back. Coupled with the lemon chili to give it a little heat, and Kai Lian on the side completes the experience. No better place to be when you are along depot road.

address: 1 Harbourfront Walk #03-01, Food Republic, Vivocity Singapore 098585 Singapore
comment: When I find myself in Vivocity and in need a meal, this is where I go. Giant plates of delicious Japanese food, twice the size and half the price of other Japanese restaurants that may not make the food as well.I've known of this place for about a year. Back then, I thought of it as an udon place -- they used to sell mentaiko udon, which was delicious. Sadly, it's no longer available. However, I discovered their Japanese charcoal grill, which is fantastic! And they also do excellent fried foods, like chicken and pork katsu, and croquettes. My meal today was a chicken katsu donburi, which is a giant chicken cutlet with egg and onions on top. The entire giant plate was only $8.50! My companion had a heaping of grilled beef and chicken with Japanese curry for $10.90, and it's some of the best grilled beef around. I have tried their ramen my previous visit, and I think it's a way better idea to get the meat dishes. You won't regret it. Just make sure you are prepared for the size of the meal because I have seen people throw away so much food from this place just because they give too much. *tear* Such a waste!

address: 1 Harbourfront Walk #03-01, Food Republic, Vivocity Singapore 098585 Singapore
comment: Have lunch at their Telok Ayer branch curry rice is reasonably price with soup and salad and green tea . Ebi a big small rice is big portion. Place is crowded and service by Japanese staff is quick

address: Blk 151 Ang Mo Kio Ave 5 #01-3030 Singapore 560151 Singapore
comment: We chanced upon this restaurant by accident and saw the huge crowd and busy activities. So we decided to give it a try. We asked a customer eating his sliced fish soup if it's delicious and he said it's very tasty and the fish is very fresh. So we decided to order it. True to the recommendation, its indeed very delicious and we also saw their kitchen dishing out numerous bowls of sliced fish bee hoon soups be the trays. We also ordered their sliced fish hor fun - very tasty too. Their fried vegetables are rather salty. Overall, the service is very friendly and the price is reasonable. Will definitely be my regular place to go!

Better value than the overpriced bad service Heng Long teochew porridge!!Fast service.. great taste and efficient staff.Coffee's great.Don't order the bean curds.. uncle says stopped selling a year ago..But the poster still showing!!Great for a hot meal!!

Was in a crave for congee. Did some googling and this place came up. It was definitely worth the 18 minutes drive. The line wasn't so bad when I arrive at 8.30am but shortly after, a long snakey line form up. Most people ordered to go and they have an excellent number queing and seating waiting area, almost like going for your Covid vaccination. Extremely orderly. Best part, the food was excellent! I ordered the pork congee with extra pork ball.  2 thumbs up

One of the best porridge located at the north east area. Never failed to order 田鸡 to go along with any porridge. Today I tried their 皮蛋花生粥, simply delicious. If you are not a fan of 田鸡, you can just try their signature porridge with overloaded ingredients. Confirm plus chop you will be bloated after 1 serving! Parking is not an issue, huge open space carpark just need to worry if it rains. Be prepared to wait at least 10-15mins just to be seated and another 10-15mins for the dishes (during peak hour).
Great porridgeMy only sadness is that there is no delivery service with this outlet.Could someone please get them on deliveroo/Uber eat?
Was ard Buangkok area looking for food and come across this on Yelp. No regrets. Price is considered very fair for the quality and quantity. Strongly recommended.

Very velvety smooth porridge. Priced at $4.50, their  lean pork century egg porridge are loaded with ingredients. Lean pork is simply marinated and tender. I didn't have to season my porridge further as it tasted just how I like. They use styrofoam bowl for takeaway. Mine remain warm and tasted good even after an hour.

For a person who don't have a taste for porridge, I would say the porridge served here is very good. The ingredients they used are very fresh and the portion is very generous too! For the price you pay ($3.50 - $5.00) you would get a big bowl of congee. I can legitimately say that this is the only place I would eat porridge at so if you have not tried the food here yet,I highly recommend you to try the porridge here!!! I've tried the Meat ball porridge which I added peanuts to it. The meatballs we're really fresh and the congee had the perfect viscosity to it! The peanuts complimented the meatball congee perfectly and overall one of the best porridge I ate in my life. Meatball and peanuts porridge - 9/10
Wah this porridge is super super nice. Definitely must try. It's cheap and delicious. Tried the fish porridge and minced meat porridge. Both are very smooth and nice.

I was driving around looking for food when I finally decided to stop and try out this shop that sells all kinds of Porridge.Ever wonder what to give your toddler for lunch or dinner when you don't cook ? Then try this, the porridge is so hot then it zap any bacteria or virus of any kind !Basically their menu has 3 versions, one is normal egg with your variety of pork related porridge, other is century egg with your variety of pork related porridge or No egg with your variety of pork related porridge. Can also order "KOSONG" which is plain porridge with or without seasonings or condiments. They also have "frog porridge" which I have not tried yet.One of the best pork porridge I have tried. They will scoop out plain porridge from one big pot to cook with your choice of pork meat balls, pork intestines, pork liver ETC. And they also have side dishes like fritters and yu sheng.So stop having mediocre porridge at those lousy food courts and try this instead !

Accidental find. Was in the neighborhood and I chanced upon this store. Porridge is delicious. Don't forget to order raw fish. Highly recommended. Might have to wait for your order if you visit during the usual peak hours.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: A lovely spot in the middle of the garden. Great air conditioning and nice ambience. Lovely patient wait staff is a nice bonus. Food wise, the dishes were average. I don't feel wow'd but they are decent. Skip the beef cheek Benedict though. While tender and soft, it was devoid of any beefy flavors.The waffle is worth a mention. Love the crispy outside!

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: This is one of my favourite casual dinning place. Though menu is not that great, the food is. It's a bit pricy but the ambiance more than makes up for it.  Pet friendly place so be prepared for the barking. My recommendation is to go for the chicken parmigiana. Big slap of chicken and rich in cheese. Service is good. Really nothing to complain about.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: The setting and ambience look nice but don't be fooled. Beneath the shiny veneer is some really lackluster food that's not worth the asking price. Had brunch with family here and service was spotty and the food wasn't timed well at all.  Dishes were coming out sporadically with long waits between them. Someone had asked if they could omit bacon from the avocado wrap but we were told they couldn't because they are pre-rolled. I mean that's pretty lazy shit if you can't make an avocado wrap to order. Ironically I ordered the avocado roll and was among the last to be served even though it was already pre-made and all they did was microwave it. You can taste the lack of effort in the wrap which was a trend repeated among all the other dishes from salmon in broth to the angus cheeseburger - sloppy, lacking flavor, and miserly portions. The only saving grace is that the space is quite comfortable but hardly worth the price. You can get way better elsewhere.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: Meals came out one at a time, in such a fashion that each person was finished eating before the next. It's Mother's Day and Mom had to wait until everyone else finished eating to get food. Not cool at all. Food is just average.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: The only bright spot about this place is that it has an outdoor seating area for dog owners and their pets. And that is about as good as it gets. Many have commented about the food, which is just decent, nothing spectacular. I'm not so generous. It was food that I could have prepared at home, and probably would have made it better. And for the price they charge, you do feel cheated. Especially since it's park land, and rental suppose to be lower. And then there's the service, which many point out as a positive. I do agree, the staff are friendly, but they could be a lot more efficient and attentive to details. For example, we were a table of 6, but they only provided 5 sets of cutlery in the little pail, coffee came without the sugar etc. And so there was always the additional need to summon their attention when it could have been avoided. And don't get me started about how long it took to settle the bill, longer than it took to eat my salad!So go, but only if you have a dog. There's little reason otherwise.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: The food is good and the setting in a garden is pretty! The service was bad as it was obvious the restaurant is understaffed for a Sunday lunch/brunch. Ignored 3a few times by the waitresses to take orders. It took the next table to help let the waitress know of our existence. Thought we were smiling and friendly? Or is it our color?

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: Great for kids. Service is very good. We live nearby and this has become one of our regular places to grab a casual dinner at.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: Peaceful environment to catch up with friends and family.Sometimes it's the environment that sets the tone for your meet up. The peaceful and considerably quiet environment created a nice, calming ambience which is great for catch up with friends without the need to shout across tables. We had 1 toddler and 1 baby in toll, felt the environment made the kids more relaxed.I have been to this park many times but this is my first time dining at this cafe. We were there at 9am, and were the only customers for quite awhile before 4 more patrons arrived.Almost all of us ordered the grilled breakfast. A decent size/portion for the price. It was enjoyable and filling. Their coffee was not great though. Latte felt bland.The parking lot is directly in front of the cafe which is great. There are also bus stop which are very close by too.Overall, a peaceful cafe to hang out with friends and families.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: Such a lovely setting for a restaurant but I was disappointed by the food. It wasn't bad but it could have been so much better. My daughter had chicken nuggets and French fries. The nuggets looked and tasted like cheap, frozen ones - they're so easy to make from scratch! I'm pretty certain the fries were frozen out of a bag too. I had the cheese burger which while tasty, loved the bacon jam, came on a pre-made bun. Again, so easy to make from scratch. Husband had the avocado wrap which looked and tasted great.Service was pretty good and as I mentioned it is a lovely setting inside the park. I'm thinking that if you just did the brunch options the food might be better but I was quite underwhelmed by the experience.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: The restaurant is set in a very relaxing environment that is great for a dinner with close friends, or even a romantic date as long as your date does not mind the occasional barking due to the proximity to dog areas even when seated indoors.Made a reservation via Chope and getting seated was fuss free. We were there on a Saturday evening and I believe that you should not have any problems getting a seat even without reservations as Bishan Park is not the busiest place to hang out in during the weekends. The menu is extensive, with pizzas, pastas and mains like Beef Bourguignon and Yorkshire Pork Rack.For my group of 4 at dinner, we ordered 1 Sakura Chicken (friend's comment - delicious!), mushroom soup (did not ask for comment) and 3 Yorkshire Pork Racks.A minor disappointment happened right here with the pork racks. Only 1 was served and the other 2 were not looking like they were appearing, so we checked with the staff. The staff came back to us to say that the pork racks were 'on the way'. From there, we waited long enough for them to have cooked the pork racks from scratch so they definitely forgot the 2 other pork racks. Would have been great if the dishes were served together, but mistakes do happen. Would have loved if we were told that the dishes were missed out but understand that some customers may throw a fit right then and there if this was mentioned.When my pork rack finally came out, it was tender, and delicious. The lovely layer of fat was very scrumptious and the mashed potatoes were creamy and had me lapping up every last bit of it. The pork rack was easy to handle, and did I say it was delicious? However, I do have to bring up something less than ideal about the pork rack. I believe that they might have been rushing to serve the pork rack due to having forgotten it prior, so the meat was actually rather pink in the middle. I chose not to sent the food back to the kitchen and I do think this was an exception to the norm, so this should not discourage you from ordering the pork rack.All in, this was worth a visit and you should drop by. Just tell them to pay attention to the pork if you are squeamish about blood.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: Nested within Bishan Partk- this restaurant is quite a quaint and green departure from the usual restaurant concealed within a shopping mall ... or perched, semi-alfresco, off the ground floor of a restored shophouse! Ordered its eggs benedict, which was described on the menu to come with "perfectly poached eggs" - at below $15! Eggs were indeed "perfectly poached" Sufficiently savory, but somehow lacklustre as a whole! I guess the poached eggs could really do with more hollandaise sauce!Had its sticky date dessert dish which was the only tempting item in the sweets section of the menu! Would give it a 6 out of 10!Lovely service! Good prices! But the place is just a tad too inaccessible for diners who don't drive. For diners who drive - loads of parking lots just outside of the restaurant on a Sunday afternoon!

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: The canopy garden dining and bar is set within the refurbished bishan park which makes it a nice setting for a weekend brunch or drinks after dinner.Their eggs benedict and eggs florentine are both quite good. I have also tried their okonomiyaki pancake and it just tasted a bit strange. I just didn't get it.I have been here for drinks and would not really reccommend it for the quality for their drinks. But the ambience is actually quite good for a quiet chat. So, just focus on the surroundings and your company, more than the drinks available.Another thing about canopy is that dogs are allowed in here, which is very cool. So there are quite a few pet owners with their dogs here especially during weekends. Hence, if you are allergic to furry cute dogs, it may be a good idea to steer clear during the weekends.I think the food, drinks and service really warrants about 3 stars but I just really like the idea of dining within a lovely park so this gets 3.5 stars! Do try this place if you are in the area.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: Not really sure how to categorize this place since it is a restaurant and cafe in the day that serves brunch and mains, but in the evenings they kinda turn into sort of a 1 Twenty Six type of garden bar/pub. I do know that this is quite a hidden find and a cool spot to visit. Situated in the very pleasant Bishan Park, you can drive in and park quite easily. Walk a little inside and you're surrounded by greenery. It is very cooling even in the day and doggie-friendly. At night it transforms into a great place for some drinks (slightly overpriced) with a easy and open-air atmosphere.For a place like Bishan/AMK, this place just adds a bit more of the chic-ness to the area that is not too heartland. Great for dates!

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: Quite a unique place this.  With a cafe style restaurant with indoor and outdoor seating, hidden in the greenery further into the 'garden' you will find The Middle Rock bar or a further cafe restaurant called The Green Room which is an Eco-dining affair.Actually all three form what is described as an Australian style dining cafe food experience.  Having not been to Australia I can't confirm or deny this claim but what I do know is that the food is good, the service relaxed and the beer cold!We visited early evening with a couple of three year olds and sat in the garden with its very welcome large cooling fans whirring away.  Our girls had pizza and fish and chips from the kids menu whilst the adults had a salad, pasta carbonara, Sakura chicken and a wagyu burger.  All the food was good although I am still getting used to the Singaporean way of delivering plates at varying times with little regard for people having to wait for their fellow diners!  Seemingly they bring it out when it's ready - pros and cons.Traveling with a gluten and lactose intolerant sweet toothed wife is a trial sometimes as dessert inevitably ends up being a choice of fruit or sorbet, however with The Green Room nearby Canopy was able to offer, from the menu, a rice based chocolate cake with vegan ice cream - we were very impressed and super pleased!The prices seem pretty standard for Singapore which is a little more than we would expect to pay at home with alcoholic drinks being quite expensive and don't forget that tax and service are on top of the menu price.However we had a lovely time in a pretty setting and would recommend anyone try it.  Don't forget the mosquito spray though when spending an evening in Bishan Park.

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: a really nice spot in the park so much potential but the food was so so. service was extremely slow. cant say id recommend it unless these things changed

address: 1382 Ang Mo Kio Ave 1 Bishan Park 2 Singapore 569931 Singapore
comment: I just had a bad experience with Canopy. Their service is horrible.1. I wanted to make a phone reservation... Called three times but no one pick up.2. Walk in and was left standing outside waited for 3 mins before someone serves us.3. Ice water are served without coaster. I'm not trying to be fussy here.. But don't you know water vapor is going to make my table wet?4. We ordered a hot chocolate and a hot chai vanilla... Drinks order came in 30 MINS AFTER my order. What  make things worse.. Both drinks are NOT even HOT.. They are only slightly warm. It feels like drinks prepared are left there for sometime before serving it!5. We ordered an Egg Benedict and Scramble Eggs with Smoked Salmon... Waited for 45 mins.. Food is not served.. Waited for 55 mins.. Realize other tables who came later than us got served earlier than us! Called a waiter and told the waiter to check our orders as we have waited for almost one hour and other people got served first. Waiter said okay.. We waited for ANOTHER 10 mins.. Not only the food is NOT SERVED, the Waiter did not even follow up on our request.6. We got really pissed and called another waiter to cancel all our orders and called for bill.  Bill came without any apology. Paid for the half drank drinks and seriously with such service I really feel like walking out without paying a single cent bcos I do not think they deserve it.Seriously if the waiting time is so long, please inform customer prior their order. Even if you screw up our orders, I would expect a simple apology to be given and to expedite on our request.No follow up, no apology, no info... Just bad service.I'm utterly disappointed with their service and hope they take this feedback seriously else they are going to lose much more customer in the future.

Amazing value and totally underrated. Dine in air con, the roasted pork is so crispy!! This is so much better than fook kin at killiney road. The owner is friendly, lots of dining space, got round tables for families. The xo seafood fried rice $8.80 comes with fish, two prawns and 3 scallops! Wok hei damn strong, must order!!!

address: 210 Ang Mo Kio Ave 9 # 01-208 Yio Chu Kang Stadium Singapore 569777 Singapore
comment: I visited Sakura on a weekday lunch, 30th Dec 2014 Tuesday. I was shocked to see a queue of at least 20 people at the entrance. Everyone apparently had a reservation as well. We had a party of 10 with a reservation as well, but we were told that one person had to stand in line and make the payment for all 10, and the remaining 9 could go in and get a seat. So take note, to have all your cash ready to make payment before your enter.Sakura had just undergone a renovation and here's their new interior. Gone are the old bambo/fake japanese looking deco. It looks alot bigger and roomier than it used to.Here is their fresh fruits, jelly and cold desserts section. I tried their mango sago and I found it too sweet and thick. The blueberry yogurt jelly tasted like a yakult pudding and it was quite nice. There was a cooked food counter which was churning out Hokkien Prawn Mee, Oyster Omelette and Fried Carrot Cake. So here is their prawn mee with a pretty huge prawn. There was some wok hei to it, and tasted decent. The Oyster Omelette was okay too, the portions are just right for your to test taste. The PRC uncle will ring a bell to tell you that the food is ready for collection. Here is their drink offerings, by the end of our buffet at 1:30pm there was no more ice and no one came to refill it. The lunch buffet ends at 3pm. But when the coffee machine drawer was full and I notified a waiter, he quickly rectified the issue so we could enjoy cups of cappuccino. The coffee machine makes coffee which is mainly 1/2 cup of milk and drips of some coffee. It can be quite bitter but I enjoyed the bitterness and I nibbled on my plate of rainbow cake.I tried every cake because I have a sweet tooth and I thoroughly enjoyed their rainbow cake, durian puff which is the plain looking cream puff. The cream puff which has a white topping is actually a plain cream puff. The banana tart/cake was decently sweet, though tasting slightly artificial, since I wasn't able to eat any actual bites of banana in it.Though miniscule compared to the ones you get at cafes. It was just nice for me. The sponge was light and the butter cream was sweet enough for my liking. The rainbow cake was refilled only once during the buffet at 1:30pm as we were leaving. It was popular amongst families with young children.Sakura offers soup buns with a hole cut inside, for your to pour a small portion of soup in. The bun itself was slightly crisp, and it tasted okay with the cream of mushroom soup. The chicken karage was very crispy and tender. You could taste the thigh meat. The calamari tasted okay, but it was not crispy. The tempura vegetables were quite hard. The sushi were better than what I remembered Sakura used to have. At least they improved on that.Each table has an induction cooker with a pot of soup so here is their shabu shabu section. Lots of vegetables for anyone who aspires to be rabbit, and also fresh raw fish. Otah, Satay and even hainanese chicken, not a bad selection of local cuisines. The satay itself was okay, but every stick were drowned in satay sauce. I didn't mind the sweetness of it. The har jiong kai (fried prawn paste chicken) was crispy and very tasty. I enjoyed it. Tasted like the ones you get at the Tze Char restaurants at coffee shops.I tried their mac n cheese which on the bottom left tray and the cheese tasted very strange. Probably heavily processed cheese. The meatballs were definitely frozen, didn't taste good.Here is their sushi offerings. Quite popular with the crowd as I watched them disappear with a blink of an eye.The service staff were quick to clear our plates and they were attentive and helped refill our soups a couple of times. My worst experience from Sakuta came from the entrance at the cash register. The guy who is collecting cash/the bottleneck is also the same guy who is picking up phone calls and reservations. You could be in line waiting to give this guy hundreds of dollars, and he's starring at you but taking down a phone reservation. This needs to change, because this is what caused the long line of people outside Sakura.. TAKE OUR MONEY AND LET US EAT! All in all a decent buffet for $16.90++ for lunch. A lot of office people from the nearby industrial estate and since it is the school hollidays, alot of families with young children were seen at the buffet. Do come early, else they will sit you outside, no air con but they have oscilating fans. I did enjoy the rainbow cake :) I would re-consider this buffet again during lunch should I have a massive rainbow cake cravings. Definitely not the best rainbow cake I have had, but it is a nice treat to end the buffet lunch.
Was just passing by and happen to see a long line of people. Guess what? They were after great Chinese dishes. Lot of dishes to choose form.

address: Blk 724, Ang Mo Kio Ave 6 #01-28 Singapore 560724 Singapore
comment: located in the heart of ang mo kio central is this hawker centre. There is only one stall selling fried kway teow, so you cannot miss it! this is the $3, there was quite a lot of crispy lard and the wok hei was very strong. Nowadays, with everyone watching their waistlines, and hawkers trying to be more muslim friendly, alot of these stalls tend to avoid using lard. But this shop is still very generous with lard and hence the Fried Kway Teow tastes very authentic.

address: 205 Hougang St 21 #02-00, Heartland Mall Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: A really authentic and yummy Korean restaurant -- in Heartland Mall! Annnd according to their menu, they don't use MSG (Although I get that thirsty, MSG mouth after, but ever so slightly. Not complaining. The food is good!) I usually judge a Korean restaurant by their banchan (side dishes) and Hansik's doesn't disappoint. Fresh, delicious, free and -- best part -- unlimited (some Korean restaurants here cut you off at 2 rounds ! Usually, we're given 6-7 banchan such as: kimchi, beansprouts, mushrooms and blanched spinach. It changes all the time, but kimchi is one of the staples. The menu is quite extensive. I haven't had em all but most of what I tried, I liked. Here are some of my recommendations: Soups: soft tofu seafood stew ($16), ginseng chicken soup ($23), beef short rib soup ($18).  The soft tofu seafood stew looks spicy but it's not. You can ask them to adjust the spice level. I thought the Soybean Paste Stew ($16) was chock full of clams but a little on the salty side.   Bibimbap: Go with the Hot Stone Bibimbap ($16) for more drama and crunch. It differs from the regular Bibimbap (which comes in a regular bowl) by $2.Hot Pot: If you have 2 or more people, consider getting a hot pot to share. My favourite is the Seafood Hotpot ($43)BBQ: Best part is that they do the cooking for you!! Both chicken dishes (Spicy BBQ and Charbroiled, each at $21) are excellent. I guess it all boils down to personal taste and mood. The Spicy Chicken isn't spicy and is marinaded in gochujang (red fermented bean paste that is the base of so many Korean dishes). The Charbroiled is marinated in a soy based sauce. Beef: Was a little disappointed in the A+ Prime Ribeye ($42). I guess because it's such a fancy cut, the portion is pretty small. I ordered it with the Charbroiled Chicken and it was not as flavorful or plentiful compared to the chicken. Do note that for BBQ, you have to order a minimum of 2 dishes (chicken/beef, chicken/chicken or chicken/pork). One cool thing is that you get to "top-up" your 2 dishes with a soup, more mushrooms or steamed egg for $10. Usually a soup costs $16.    I really love their cold barley tea, and they have Hite beer and soju too. My only gripe is that service can be spotty/brusque and if you come between 7-8pm, you'll have to wait.  What I usually do is go around 6pm. Best value for money is the lunch sets. The ginseng chicken soup usually costs $20+ but for lunch it's $12+

address: 205 Hougang St 21 #02-00, Heartland Mall Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: I think the food must be darn good if I still can't stop thinking about it one week later.A friend who has lived in Korea for several years recommended this place. I must say I did not believe her much when she said it was good or that it was always crowded. Reason being it always looked empty when I passed by the place on week nights around 6pm. I guess the crowd only appears closer to 7pm and on weekends. After many months since the recommendation, I finally made it there at 630pm on a week night. The place was partially filled. I thought it was quite kind of the staff to give us a table for 4 when there were only 2 of us. I realized why when the food arrived. The beef bulgogi pot took up a lot of space! Add the banchan (7 of them), and they filled the entire table. We ordered the beef bulgogi with mushrooms for 2 persons and the quantity was more than enough to feed 3 or 4. We were stunned when we saw the amount of meat and mushrooms and tang hoon on the pot. The staff will come around to cook the food and cut the noodles and beef into more manageable sizes. The beef was tender and the mushrooms were big and juicy. Love it. The ban chan was good and we were just so filled up that we did not finish any of that. The kimchi stew was also stellar. Spicy, sour and full of cabbage and tofu. I love that instead of water, they put a jug of houjicha (cold) on the table for our consumption. The bill came to about $60+ which I thought was quite reasonable. The service was prompt and efficient. I am so glad to find a place for decent Korean food place in my area, and I no longer have to make do with those from the food courts.

address: 205 Hougang St 21 #02-00, Heartland Mall Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: Hansik Korean Restaurant is run by Koreans and I their food are authentic and really good.It costs a little more than your normal Korean restaurants, but I can guarantee that what you'll be eating is one of the best out there. I really love their BBQ chicken and beef! I would really recommend you to go for their BBQ meals. Just like how the Koreans will feast on their meal, the waiters will serve water in bottles and utensils in a small white boxes.The owners are Koreans and even though they do not know how to converse in English, they were so friendly and kind that I didn't mind the wait and patience. I'm glad there is one good Korean place in the heartlands at the North-east area. Definitely worth a go.

address: 205 Hougang St 21 #02-00, Heartland Mall Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: Hansik Korean Restaurant is Korean restaurant in Singapore, and deserves a bit more attention.Wait: 3/5 One of the two bad things about this place. Since the restaurant is quite small, we had to wait for 8 minutes although there was not many people in the queue. Service: 4/5 The service crew was very friendly and they even cooked the barbecue for us which is something unique. Food 5/5 Absolutely delicious. The barbecue beef was tender and melted in your mouth. The rest of the dishes were well-seasoned and looked stunning. I recommend the ginseng soup, the barbecue set and the bibimbap.Price: 3.5/5 The other downside of the place. The ginseng soup, which was very delicious, costed $21 and if you want extra soup, you have to pay an extra $4. The price came to about $182 for 4 people which was quite expensive. Overall: 3.75/5 While you might have to wait for a while and prepare to pay a lot, the food and service makes up for it and you should try it out.

address: 205 Hougang St 21 #02-00, Heartland Mall Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: This restaurant is located on level 2 of heartland mall, just outside of Kovan MRT station. I think it is really great as we can dine in an authentic Korean restaurant so near to home, not needed to head down to town. You can dine there for lunch or dinner and a good place to catch up with friends or family.It has an interesting concept that has the waiter serving the table personally and bbq-ing the food for customers, i really liked that so we did not have to do it ourselves. One thing i love about Korean cuisine is the kim chi and it has to taste just right else it would spoil the whole meal. The kimchi here was excellent just like the ones i had in Korea.The other dishes like beef, their pancakes and stews were all so delicious. Although they came in small portions but it was just nice as they had quite a number of dishes served. Service was great too as staff would patiently explain to us the Korean dishes and also how to place the orders.

address: 205 Hougang St 21 #02-00, Heartland Mall Singapore 530205 Singapore
comment: This place is a gem in the heartlands. I might be old-fashioned at heart, but when I go to an Italian restaurant, I would prefer if the staff was Italian. If it's Japanese sushi, I would prefer the sushi chef to be Japanese instead of some chinese guy spouting Cantonese. As such, it was a pleasant surprise that the staff at this quaint korean restaurant were all korean. True, their english is not fantastic, but I come here for good food, not for anything else so it's all good. The menu was impressive by its diversity. I was spoiled for choice because there were so many items on the menu that I couldn't decide. I ended up choosing the ginseng chicken soup since I was sick and it did not disappoint. This is the best ginseng chicken I've had in Singapore so far. The soup was tasty and the chicken was so tender. And I love the congee in it. Definitely a good choice if you're into ginseng chicken. The small dishes were good, although nothing blew me away. The seafood kimchi pancake was on the small side but the flavor was good. I loved the bibimbop here. The vegetables were fresh, the sunny side up was perfectly cooked, and the ratio of meat and vege to rice was 2:1 which is great for the carb-conscious. The tofu stew was pretty good too, has a kick in the spice department. The cold noodles were very authentic as well. We got the mushroom beef pot to share as well. I thought the beef was better bbqed than broiled in the hot pot but my sister really liked it so it's a matter of taste. Reasonable prices, no conventional crazy strong smoke smell in the restaurant (which is a big plus), good authentic food. Need I say more?

address: 61 Ang Mo Kio Ave 8 #02-03, Jubilee Square Singapore 569814 Singapore
comment: Been reading some reviews on this place & they were all pretty positive. Not a disappointing lunch for me. First of all, they have a good variety of set lunches during weekday. Affordable & tempting! The promotion is a buy 2 get 1 free deal. Too bad i went with people with tiny appetite who only wants ala carte. :(I had the chirashi bowl & the portion is HUGE! The sashimi is fresh & fantastic for $16.90? Or lesser? Can't remember the exact price. The ala carte dishes are good too according to the sparrows who dined with me.   Good service & all smiles whenever we request for nonsense like extra chopsticks. Will return!

address: 61 Ang Mo Kio Ave 8 #02-03, Jubilee Square Singapore 569814 Singapore
comment: Recently Haru Haru Japanese Restaurant is listed as one of the 12 Best Sushi Rolls In Singapore in a well known blog. It is opened not long ago, taking over the space of another Japanese restaurant called Kinsa Sushi. The decoration of the restaurant is not much different from the previous restaurant, in a modern and stylish way. As similar to the previous restaurant, the restaurant also offers lunch set at reasonable prices ranging from $12.80++ to $18.80++.One of the lunch set is Bara Chirashi Set ($14.80++), which comes with salad, appetizer, steamed egg, miso soup and fruits. It is quite a good deal considering that an ala carte order of Bara Chirashi Don costs $18.80++ for normal and $28.80++ for Premium.The steamed egg is served pipping hot and taste smooth down the throat. The miso soup is light and flavourful. The salad is served with soyu dressing, tastes light and refreshing. The appetiser is spicy chicken cubes which is refreshing cold. The bara chirashi is consists of cubes of tuna, salmon, crab stick, swordfish, egg and furikake on top of sushi rice. The mixture is quite tasty and the seafood tastes fresh too. The dish is also beautifully decorated with a flower on top.Overall the food is not bad. Staffs are quite friendly too. However there is some problems with the credit card system when I visit the place. So only cash and NETS are accepted for payment.

address: 61 Ang Mo Kio Ave 8 #02-03, Jubilee Square Singapore 569814 Singapore
comment: The fried pork in Tonkatsu Bento was not fresh. The pork looks really dark color, and does not taste fresh. The Bara chitashi filled with raw fishes, does not taste fresh either. Sushi with Mini Udon set is ok, fish sushi was fresh, but the noodle soup was rather blend. Tenpura bento suppose to spell as tempura, was not badper ly nephew. Nabe mono soup pot was not bad, soup not too salty.

address: 151 Ang Mo Kio Ave 5 Singapore 560151 Singapore
comment: Decent dim sum at an affordable price. We spent about 200 for 15 people. I prefer the steamed items than the fried ones but maybe that's a personal preference. Personal favorites include prawn dumpling and Xiao long baos. No photos though- too many hungry people!

Asiago bread with olive oil and balsamic vinegar!! Something so simple yet so delightful was the right way to set the stage for ITALIAN dining!Several tables ordered the lobster linguine, which usually comes in a big shared bowl. Although the "tomato sauce" sounded simplistic, it was some of the best I've tasted, and there were hearty chunks of lobster throughout the pasta. The lobster comes with the full shell and claws, so it might look intimidating at first, but actually most of the meat has already been cooked in with the pasta. The durian tiramisu was really worth it -- delicate flavors of Mao Shan Wang (猫山王) durian fibers interlaced with marscapone that didn't overpower the cocoa and coffee flavors -- how did the dessert chef do it?!  I myself don't particularly enjoy durian normally, but this dessert had me going back scooping for more. Light yet still pervasive durian flavors that I never thought would pair with tiramisu -- EPIC dessert!

Very delicious lobster spaghetti and the lobster meat is very generous. Good for 2-3 people to share. The seasonable durian tiramisu is uniquely singapore and it is very very good. The Mao Shang Wang durian does not over power the tiramisu and the sweetness is just right. Hurry before the durian season is over. Best grilled pork too!

In short, Mimmo has nailed it. Excellent everything. Pizza is an absolute bullseye and should put the neighbouring (and well below average) Sarpino's out of a job. Quite possibly the largest glass of wine in Singapore, and better than drinkable ($9 per glass). Buckle up: you can buy their massive and delicious bread loaves FLOWN IN FROM ITALY (why ask why?) for 7 bucks a loaf and get that freshly baked "niam!" It has been 3 years since I've enjoyed an Italian this much in SG, and that it is 500m from my front door, well, I'm just singin' in the rain. Badaboom. Coming back very soon. Bravo.
Great selection of bottled beers. Decent western food. Has Pool table and Darts upstairs.

What a little hidden gem! Good classic French good (and curiously, also Briyani!) and the fifth star is for its affordability. Really decent prices. The duck confit was delicious and really well done. Good flavour, moist meat, crispy skin. Actually there was no bad note to the entire meal - from the bread rolls all the way to dessert (excellent creme brûlée). Give this place a try! Hardly anyone there at lunch time and easy parking in basement carpark.

We made a reservation here for valentine's day and realised that the menu choice was restricted to a special V-day one. Nonetheless, we chose duck confit and beef fillet and ribs for our mains. Pan fried foie gras and baked oyster for our appetisers. I want to highlight the crispy duck and the soft beef ribs which were absolutely delicious. The pan fried foie gras was also a delight! I would return for another visit to taste their regular menu!

So I don't really want to share this little secret...but I just can't keep this one to myself. Quality French cuisine at affordable prices! A three course prix fixe meal here will cost just S$48 nett (service charge and GST included). You can choose from one of 7 appetizers, 8 entrees, and 6 desserts with top up for certain appetizers or desserts. I also enjoyed the complementary warm bread, but the butter came out firm out of the refrigerator. There's a top up for the Baked Brie Cheese and the Pan Seared Foie Gras appetizers,  but they're worth it. You can also order a la carte if you don't want all three courses.All the protein dishes were very well cooked, but I was less impressed with the vegetable sides. I felt like the vegetables were just an afterthought and not much effort was put into them, even though they're an important complement to the meat. That being said, I enjoyed everything form the crispy pork cheeks to the duck confit to the beef tenderloin. None of the desserts were very extraordinary though. Skip the extra charge for the souffle dessert as it wasn't really that great. The highlights are really the foie gras and the meats, but that's what most crave for anyway. Service was mediocre...the waiter tried to be delicate, but he was just clumsy at times. We also had to call them over a few times to ask for things. For a fancier place, the service should be more on point.

I was there with my wife and toddler girl.  We made a reservation via hungrygowhere for a party of 2 at 8pm but wasn't able to make it there until close to 9 due to work commitments.   I was surprised to see only 5 tables filled on a Friday evening but it could be because of the late hour coupled with the location.For apetitizer, we had the baked brie with pistachio.   For mains, the duck confit and the cod tempura.  We ordered the kahlua souffle for desserts and I had a Palm Amber beer.  All for sharing, of course, in typical Singapore dining style.The baked brie was really excellent and is a must try.  The various flavours on the plate complimented each other very well and we had fun mixing and matching the brie with the sauces and sides.  This is a must order for any newcomers to the restaurant.The duck confit and cod tempura were very well executed.  The flavours were typically light but sufficient and they generally work very well with each other within the plate.  The duck confit was flavoured just right for me when I usually find the dish a bit on the saltier side.  It also came with a wonderful execution on mash potatoes which, I suspect, used oil fried in shallot as a base.  Very flavourful and you cannot help but finish very last bit.The cod tempura came in a very generous 2 huge pieces portion.  The cod is very lightly battered with tempura flour and then pan fried to achieve a very thin and crispy outer layer.  The cod remains juicy inside.  It was a joy to have the flavours bursting through as you bit down past the crispy layer into the flesh of fish.  Very yummy.The kahlua souffle came well formed and the wait staff mixed in the freshly squashed passion fruit at the table after it was served.  Tasted delicious but as we were both pretty much full after the main courses, we didn't managed to finished it completely.The total bill came to just a tad under $100 at $97.50.  Black Sheep Cafe does not levy service charge and GST.
For affordable french cuisine, check this place out!

The duck no doubt is one of their best. The lamb was juicy and also highly recommended. The chocolate moose/souffle was a bit too creamy for our liking. Pricing is mid range... Ambiance was cosy. Service a bit slow.... don't go if you are in a rush. Advance booking advisable.

This is probably the authentic Vietnam food in singapore. We love the cocker dish which the way the cook so yummy. My son and I ate non stop.Highly recommend to Singaporean and Vietnamese as well The staffs are very helpful and friendly

UpdateBanh Canh Cua - 2.5 starsDidn't taste like crab and had few ingredients. Sticking to the other dishes!==========Lemongrass beef noodle dry ($9.90) - 5 starsI haven't had good Vietnamese food since leaving L.A. until Mrs Pho! It's also very reasonably priced. The flavors were excellent - the beef was juicy, flavorful and grilled to perfection. Although I got takeout and regretted not adding more of the hot sauce on the table.I'm going back for sure!!! They also have Banh Canh Cua, or crab meat noodle, which I haven't seen outside of Hanoi.

I regularly go to Mrs Pho on Beach Road so it was a nice surprise to see this new one on Rangoon Road! I really enjoy the noodles at Mrs Pho and I felt that Mrs Pho House was better with dishes than the noodles. I ordered the exact same crab noodles at Mrs Pho House and it was not as good as what I had at their Beach Road location.On the other hand though, Mrs Pho House is much more comfortable - the seats are not as cramped up and there's more room for everyone. They also offer a wider variety of dishes like Banh Xeo and Banh Khot, alongside claypot and stir-fried items.I really enjoyed their stir-fried dishes, I thought they were all very well executed. The Banh Xeo was good but not crisp enough. I liked the Banh Khot and would definitely order them again! The next time I'm there, I would love to try their claypot dishes since those crab noodles look amazing!

Been here twice. Wonderful Vietnamese food. The dry noodles and Pho were excellent so were the starfruit beef salad and the omelette salad. The Vietnam Coffee were very good, hot or cold. Will definitely return.
